title: What is Bioinformatics?
text: Bioinformatics: An interdisciplinary field that develops computational methods and software tools to analyze and interpret, complex biological datasets using biology, computer science, mathematics, and statistics.

title: What is Bioinformatics?
text:
Origin Story

1960s: Over 10 years before the development of DNA sequencing
The Edman degradation method for protein sequencing could only sequence them in small fragments of 50-60 amino acids
Margaret Dayhoff and Robert S. Ledley developed the first bioinformatics software, COMPROTEIN to assemble the fragments into the full structure of each protein

title: What is Bioinformatics?
text:
Timeline

1976: The first fully sequenced genome (Bacteriophage MS2)
1977: First easy to use personal computers hit the market
1984: The University of Wisconsin Genetics Computer Group published the ‚ÄòGCG‚Äô software suite for DNA, RNA and protein analysis.
1990: Human Genome Project initiated by the U.S. National Institutes of Health
2003: Human Genome Project completed, cost $2.7 billion (in 1991 dollars)
2014: Cost to sequence a human genome drops to $1000

title: What is Bioinformatics?
text:
Evolution of the Field

Genomics
Transcriptomics
Proteomics
Epigenomics
Gene network regulation
Phylogenetics
Systems biology
Image analysis
Machine learning

title: What is Bioinformatics?
text:
The Future of Bioinformatics

Complete multiomics of single cells
Whole organism modeling
Virtual cells
Virtual organisms
AI Scientists: Autonomous systems that can design, implement and analyze experiments independently

title: What is Bioinformatics?
text:
Skills Needed

Programming languages: R, Python and SQL
Computer skills: UNIX command-line, git
Domain knowledge: Understanding of molecular genetics
Quantitative skills: Statistics, linear algebra, machine learning
Communication skills: Translating complex analyses into insights for researchers

title: What is Bioinformatics?
text:
Questions I Help Answer

What genes are differentially expressed between conditions or treatments?
Which biological pathways are activated in disease versus healthy samples?
Which cell types are present in my single-cell or spatial transcriptomics data?

title: What is Bioinformatics?
text:
Thank you!

Questions?

text: Welcome to my collection of presentations and talks. Each presentation is built with Quarto and RevealJS.

title: Welcome To My Blog
text: Welcome! This is the first post in my new Quarto blog. I will be sharing bioinformatics content here, my goal is to make the tutorials and content I share as approachable as possible with an emphasis on developing practical skills.

title: CLAUDE.md
text:
This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.


This is a personal website built with Quarto, featuring blog posts and RevealJS presentations about bioinformatics. The site is hosted on GitHub Pages and uses the ‚ÄúNatBytes‚Äù branding.



This project uses Quarto for building the website. Quarto must be installed on the system separately.



Quarto uses bootstrap: https://getbootstrap.com/docs/5.3/customize/sass/


Render the entire website:
quarto render
Preview the website locally with live reload:
quarto preview
Render a specific file:
quarto render path/to/file.qmd
Render a specific presentation:
quarto render presentations/what_is_bioinformatics/index.qmd



The website builds to the docs/ directory (configured in _quarto.yml with output-dir: docs), which is the standard directory for GitHub Pages deployment from the main branch.




The project uses renv for R package management:

R Version: 4.3.3
Python Version: 3.12.2 (virtualenv in ./renv/python/virtualenvs/)
Lockfile: renv.lock contains all package dependencies

The .Rprofile file automatically activates the renv environment when R starts.



.
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ _quarto.yml           # Main Quarto configuration
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.qmd             # Home page (blog posts listing)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ about.qmd             # About page
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ posts/                # Blog posts directory
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ _metadata.yml     # Shared metadata for posts
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ welcome/          # Individual post directories
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ presentations/        # Presentations directory
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.qmd         # Presentations listing page
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ what_is_bioinformatics/
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.qmd     # Presentation slides
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ mytheme.scss  # Custom RevealJS theme
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ images/       # Presentation images
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ plots/        # Presentation plots
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/                 # Build output (published to GitHub Pages)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ renv/                 # R package library
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ styles.css            # Global site styles






Posts live in posts/ with each post in its own subdirectory
Each post is a .qmd file with YAML frontmatter
The home page (index.qmd) uses Quarto‚Äôs listing feature to automatically display posts sorted by date
Posts can have categories and are rendered with default listing layout





Presentations use Quarto‚Äôs RevealJS format
Each presentation lives in its own subdirectory under presentations/
Presentations can have custom SCSS themes (see below)
Images and plots are stored in subdirectories within each presentation folder
The presentations index page manually lists presentations with descriptions and links




The _quarto.yml file controls: - Project type: website with output to docs/ - Theme: Dual theme setup (light: flatly, dark: solar) - Navigation: Right-aligned navbar with About, Posts (index), GitHub, and Bluesky links - Custom CSS: styles.css for additional styling




Presentations use SCSS for theming, structured in two sections within a .scss file:


Defaults section (/*-- scss:defaults --*/): - Define variables starting with $ to control colors, fonts, and spacing - Common variables include $body-bg, $body-color, $presentation-heading-font, $link-color, $presentation-list-bullet-color - Variables marked with !default can be overridden - Import custom fonts using @import url() statements - All custom themes inherit from Quarto‚Äôs default theme
Rules section (/*-- scss:rules --*/): - Define custom CSS rules that override default styles - Target elements within .reveal class for presentation-specific styling - Use CSS custom properties (e.g., --r-bold-color) for reusable values - Can style specific slide elements like title slides using IDs (e.g., #title-slide)



In the presentation‚Äôs YAML frontmatter:
format:
  revealjs:
    theme: mytheme.scss
Or layer with built-in themes:
format:
  revealjs:
    theme: [default, mytheme.scss]



The existing theme demonstrates: - Custom color palette variables ($teal, $surfblue, $yellow, $orange) - Google Fonts imports (News Cycle, Lato) - Overriding presentation variables ($presentation-heading-font, $body-bg, etc.) - Custom styling for bold/italic text, list bullets, and progress bars - Title slide positioning adjustments using transforms







Create a new directory in posts/ (e.g., posts/my-post/)
Create index.qmd with YAML frontmatter including title, date, and categories
Write content using Quarto markdown
Run quarto render to build





Create a new directory in presentations/ (e.g., presentations/my-talk/)
Create index.qmd with RevealJS format in YAML frontmatter
Use --- to separate slides
Create images/ and plots/ subdirectories as needed
Optionally create a custom .scss theme file (see theming section above)
Update presentations/index.qmd to add the new presentation to the listing
Run quarto render to build





The site is deployed to GitHub Pages from the docs/ directory on the main branch. After rendering, commit changes to both source files and the docs/ directory, then push to GitHub.
The CNAME file contains the custom domain configuration, and .nojekyll prevents GitHub from processing the site with Jekyll.
